Has anyone heard of the Mo Movie Measure? It says that a film is "adequately feminist" if:
 
 1) It has two women
 2) that talk to each other
 3) about something other than a man.
 
 Seems like a pretty low standard, right? And yet when I look at some of my favorite movies...
 
 Star Wars: Never two speaking women in the same scene.
 Raiders of the Lost Ark: Only one woman with lines?
 Casablanca: I don't think two women ever talk to each other.
 
 How do other people's favorite movies do?

Well, let's see...
 Armageddon had 3 woman of any consequence. They never talked to eachother at all.
 Forrest Gump had 2 woman of any consequence. Jenny and Forrest's mom. They never talked to eatherother.
 
 How would these do? Also, do the list of 3 things do mean the movie is good or bad?

How would these do? Also, do the list of 3 things do mean the movie is good or bad?

 
 I don't think good or bad is the point, per se. The idea is to illustrate what short shrift women get in movies. I never really noticed before until I applied what seems like a really low standard and saw how few films passed it. It seems like in movies the default gender is male, and you only use a woman if the script requires it. Not all movies, of course, but a surprising number.

Lord of the Rings has three somewhat substantial female roles, but they do not talk to each other. Eowyn has a pretty good fight against standard male roles, and I appreciate that.
 
 Other favorite movies of mine...Airplane!. No. Any Monty Python. No. Woody Allen movies? Eh...not really. Office Space? No. Trying to think of comedies that fit...having a hard time.
 
 Wow, even though these standards are low, there's not a lot of movies that I enjoy that fit the bill. I'm not a fan of "chick flicks"; there's probably quite a few in that genre.

Woody Allen movies? Eh...not really. 

 
 Ants. The queen talks to the princess about having babies. Animated insect women, but I'd say it still counts.
Sure Amidala and Padme talk briefly in Episode 1. Pretty sure Mon Mothma and Leia talk to each other as well at some point in the trilogy.

Gone With the Wind:
 
 lots of women that talk to each other.. erm or rather at each other... maybe that isn't the best example

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Mo Movie Measure
